issues.description: Return type mismatch for Animal.messageOnFeed(): the problem statement (UML and textual descriptions) specifies messageOnFeed() returns a String and examples in the task expect String values (e.g. "Arf Arf!", "Oink!", "Maah!"). The solution repository instead defines messageOnFeed() to return a FeedResponse object (solution: Animal.messageOnFeed(): FeedResponse and FeedResponse class introduced). This is a structural inconsistency: students implementing the method as specified in the problem (returning String) will diverge from the solution's type, and automated tests or provided solution code that expects FeedResponse would not match the students' implementations.
issues.suggested_fix:
Make the return type for messageOnFeed() consistent across all artifacts. Two options (choose one and apply across problem statement, template, and solution):

1) Keep the simpler pedagogical contract from the problem statement: change the solution to have messageOnFeed() return String (remove/avoid FeedResponse). Update Animal.java to declare public abstract String messageOnFeed(); update Pig/Seal/Goat to return the String messages ("Oink!", "Arf Arf!", "Maah!") and remove the FeedResponse class. Ensure Farm printing and singFarmSong use those Strings directly.

2) If FeedResponse is intentionally required, update the problem statement and UML to state that messageOnFeed() returns a FeedResponse (and describe the class), and update template examples/descriptions so students know to return a FeedResponse rather than a String. Also update the song/printing instructions to use the FeedResponse.toString() or its message getter.

Apply the chosen fix to all three artifact sets so students are not confused by conflicting expected types.

issues.description: The problem statement and UML require Animal.messageOnFeed() to return a String (students are instructed that messageOnFeed() returns strings like "Arf Arf!", "Oink!", "Maah!"). The solution repository instead defines messageOnFeed() to return a FeedResponse object (and adds a new FeedResponse class), with Pig and Seal returning new FeedResponse(...). This introduces a new conceptual entity (FeedResponse) and a different return type for the same method students are asked to implement, which is likely to confuse students mapping the specification to the reference implementation and the starter/template code.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the method signature and conceptual model across artifacts. Either (A) change the solution to match the problem and template by making Animal.messageOnFeed() return a String (update Animal.java, Pig.java, Seal.java to return String and remove or repurpose FeedResponse), or (B) explicitly update the problem statement and template to document and require a FeedResponse return type (describe the purpose/fields of FeedResponse) so students expect the FeedResponse abstraction. Recommended: prefer option (A) for minimal student cognitive load — return String messages as described in the exercise.
